successfulResults.originalText: Forgotten Star Dorothy Stratten Almost Lived the Hollywood Fairy Tale. It Ended as a Horror Story....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Dorothy Stratten's story was almost perfect.

* She was a beautiful actress.
* She was famous in Hollywood.
* She had a happy marriage.

But her story ended badly.

* She was murdered by her husband.
...

successfulResults.originalText: Peter Bogdanovich, Bob Fosse, and Hugh Hefner all loved her, in their own ways—for better and worse. This reexamination of Stratten’s life, rape, and murder casts a new light on the angel who was a ce...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
They loved her: Peter, Bob, and Hugh.

* Peter Bogdanovich liked her.
* Bob Fosse liked her.
* Hugh Hefner liked her.

They all liked her in different ways....

successfulResults.originalText: PICTURE PERFECT Dorothy Stratten was still in high school when she entered the Great Playmate Hunt....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Dorothy Stratten was a teenager when she entered a contest.

* The contest was called the Great Playmate Hunt.
* It was for a magazine called Playboy....

successfulResults.originalText: Steve Schapiro/Getty Images....
successfulResults.simplifiedText: Steve Schapiro is a photographer....

successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Snider hired a detective to watch Dorothy.

* He wanted to know if she was cheating on him.
* He thought she might be with Bogdanovich.

A movie was made about detectives.
It had a man who looked like...

Dorothy went to a lawyer on August 13.

* She said she wanted to end her marriage to Snider.
* She also said she wanted to help Snider financially.

On August 14, Dorothy went to Snider's house.

* Sh...

successfulResults.originalText: It’d been exactly two years and one day since Dorothy left Canada....
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
It's been 2 years and 1 day since Dorothy left Canada.

* 2 years is a long time.
* Dorothy left Canada a long time ago....

successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Here is the text rewritten in simple language:

There are many people telling a story. But the people in the story are not real. They are symbols.

Dorothy and Paul are like characters in a fairy tale...

successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Teller number one is Teresa Carpenter.

She wrote an article called "Death of a Playmate." It was in a newspaper called The Village Voice on November 5, 1980.

The last lines of her article say:

* Pa...

successfulResults.originalText: “In the end Dorothy Stratten was less memorable for herself than for the yearnings she evoked,” Carpenter concludes. (See what I mean? Carpenter is shitcanning Dorothy as the star of her own story.) “...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Carpenter says Dorothy is not the main story.

* She is more famous for what she made people feel.
* People wanted different things from her:
 * Snider wanted the score (the music).
 * Hefner wanted a...

successfulResults.originalText: Hefner as a pornographer...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Hefner was a man who made adult movies.

* He made these movies for people to watch.
* He wanted to show sex in a new way.
* He started a magazine to show these movies.
* The magazine was called Playb...

successfulResults.originalText: That someone viewed Hefner as a pornographer shouldn’t have come as a shock to him, and yet I suspect it did. Pornographers, after all, were furtive little men, guilt-ridden and bound by loneliness. A...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Hefner thought he was different. But some people saw him as a bad person.

* A bad person makes and shows sex pictures.
* Hefner did this kind of thing.

He was a public figure. People knew him well. ...

successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Hefner thought he made a big change.

* He said he helped change how people think about sex.
* He said this more than once.

Hefner also thought he was a hero for people's rights.
* He protected the r...

When you talk about Hefner's pictures:

* They were not just for sex.
* People thought they were art.

Miki Garcia agrees. She was a Playmate in 1973. She said: "Hef made pictures that were nice. You ...

People in Hollywood do not respect Hefner.

* They go to his parties.
* They play games with him.
* But they do not think he is important.

One way Hefner can be more important is to find new stars.

* They had to sign contracts to work for him.

These contracts controlled the women. They had to do ...

When you think of Hefner, you might think he was a king. But he was also a beggar.

Hollywood made him a beggar. They made him a host too. He was the host at the Mansion in Holmby Hills.

* He was not a part of the main group in Hollywood.
* He wanted to be friends with them, but they didn't accept him.

successfulResults.originalText: A few months later, in the fall of ’81, Bogdanovich sold a proposal for a memoir about his time with Dorothy. “It’s a story which must be told,” he said to a reporter, “and I’ll tell it.”...
successfulResults.simplifiedText:
Bogdanovich sold a plan for a book.
